summary: RT-PCR on NPA became available to us in mid-March. we included 218 patients who had nasopharyngeal RT-PCR performed at illness onset. NPA samples were examined by rapid immunofluorescence antigen detection methods. 4.2 L of eluted RNA was reverse-transcribed with use of reverse transcriptase. mixture was incubated at room temperature for 10 min and then at 42°C for 15 min. reaction was stopped at 95°C for 5 min and then chilled in ice. treatment All patients received treatment according to a standard protocol. an antiviral drug (ribavirin 24 mg/kg/day intravenously, together with hydrocortisone 10 mg/kg/day) administered if symptoms did not respond within 48 h. patients Two hundred sixty-seven patients fulfilling CDC case definition for suspected or probable SARS were admitted to the isolation wards of the Princess Margaret Hospital from February 26, 2003 to March 31, 2003. RT-PCR on NPA became available to us in mid-March. 4.2 L of eluted RNA was reverse-transcribed with use of reverse transcriptase. mixture was incubated at room temperature for 10 min and then at 42°C for 15 min. reaction was stopped at 95°C for 5 min and then chilled in ice. treatment All patients received treatment according to a standard protocol. an antiviral drug (ribavirin 24 mg/kg/day intravenously, together with hydrocortisone 10 mg/kg/day) was administered if symptoms did not respond within 48 h. nasopharyngeal RT-PCR was performed on 90 male and 128 female patients. all patients, except six, were Chinese; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.1 to 38.0. the clinical features of our cohort were rather nonspecific. anemia, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia were common on admission. symptoms might reflect peripheral consumption or bone marrow suppression by the infection. sensitivity of stool samples for RT-PCR tests was 97% (mean of 14.2 days). in patients with negative RT-PCR results on NPA samples, none had a stool sample positive by RT-PCR. negative result may not represent low viral load in patients and vice versa. the maximum viral replication by quantitative RT-PCR occurred by approximately day 10. but the clinical worsening seemed to lag behind this peak. a positive RT-PCR result had no correlation to development of acute respiratory distress syndrome. sensitivity of RT-PCR test was 74.7% when an antibody test was used as a standard, which can be explained by the variation in the technique and timing of sampling. the optimal timing for the RT-PCR test is unknown. the controversy of medication in the management of SARS has never been settled. current treatment guidelines proposed by the Hospital Authority of Hong Kong are still in use despite the adverse effects of the suggested treatment.
